title: Single-cell atlas reveals immune regulation of human tissue development
abstract: A comprehensive single-cell atlas of human immune cells reveals crucial variations in immune cell populations across different ancestral backgrounds. Multi-omic profiling of T cells, B cells, and dendritic cells shows population-specific differences in gene expression and chromatin accessibility. These findings have important implications for personalized medicine and understanding immune diversity.

title: Multi-omic mapping of human immune cell diversity across populations
abstract: We present a multi-omic analysis of immune cells from diverse human populations, revealing significant genetic and epigenetic variation. Our atlas integrates RNA sequencing, protein expression, and chromatin accessibility data from over 500 individuals across Asian, European, and African ancestries. Population-specific immune signatures were identified in T cell and dendritic cell compartments.

title: Functional genomics of immune cells in Asian populations
abstract: Large-scale functional genomics study of peripheral blood immune cells from Chinese and Japanese cohorts. We identified population-specific expression quantitative trait loci and chromatin accessibility patterns that differ from European reference data. These results highlight the importance of diverse reference populations for precision medicine.

title: Genetic and epigenetic diversity in human T cell populations
abstract: Analysis of T cell gene expression and epigenetic modifications across global populations reveals ancestry-specific regulatory mechanisms. We catalogued genetic variants affecting immune cell function in East Asian populations that are rare in European cohorts. Multi-omic integration identified novel circadian rhythm regulators in immune cells.

title: Human immune cell atlas: Population variation and clinical implications
abstract: Comprehensive atlas of immune cell types across diverse human populations. Single-cell RNA sequencing and protein profiling reveal population-specific immune signatures in dendritic cells and T cells. These findings are critical for developing ethnicity-appropriate immunotherapies and understanding differential disease susceptibility.

title: Age and sex differences in immune cell populations: A multi-omic study
abstract: Multi-omic profiling of immune cells from individuals aged 20-77 years reveals age-associated changes in inflammatory cell populations and dendritic cell gene expression. Sex-specific differences were observed in T cell function and cytokine production. Integration of genomic, transcriptomic, and proteomic data provides insights into immune aging.

title: Cross-population comparison of immune system genomics
abstract: We compared immune system genomics across Chinese, Japanese, and European populations using single-cell multi-omics. Significant differences were found in regulatory variants affecting immune cell function. Population-specific alleles regulating circadian clock genes in immune cells were identified in East Asian cohorts.

title: Chromatin accessibility and gene regulation in human immune cells
abstract: Genome-wide analysis of chromatin accessibility in human peripheral blood immune cells reveals population-specific regulatory elements. Multi-omic integration of ATAC-seq, RNA-seq, and proteomics data from diverse cohorts identifies ancestry-specific enhancers regulating immune function. Important implications for understanding immune diversity.

title: Personalized immunology: Population variation in immune cell function
abstract: Large-scale study of immune cell function across global populations reveals the need for population-specific medical interventions. Analysis of blood samples from Chinese, European, and Japanese individuals shows significant variation in immune cell responses. Multi-omic profiling identifies ancestry-specific mechanisms in T cells and dendritic cells.

title: Single-cell immunology atlas of Asian populations
abstract: Comprehensive single-cell atlas of immune cells from Asian populations provides reference data for precision medicine. Analysis of over 10 million cells reveals population-specific immune signatures and regulatory variants. Comparison with European data sets highlights the importance of diverse reference populations in immunology research.

title: Highly accurate protein structure prediction with AlphaFold
abstract: Proteins are essential to life, and understanding their structure can facilitate a mechanistic understanding of their function. Through an enormous experimental effort, the structures of around 100,000 unique proteins have been determined, but this represents a small fraction of the billions of known protein sequences. Structural coverage is bottlenecked by the months to years of painstaking effort required to determine a single protein structure. Accurate computational approaches are needed to address this gap and to enable large-scale structural bioinformatics.

title: Attention Is All You Need
abstract: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely.

title: Climate change and the selective signature of the Late Ordovician mass extinction
abstract: Mass extinctions have profoundly influenced the history of life, but their selectivity patterns and causes remain controversial. We analyzed Late Ordovician fossil occurrences to assess which factors best predict genus extinction.

title: Safety and Efficacy of the BNT162b2 mRNA Covid-19 Vaccine
abstract: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection and the resulting coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) have afflicted tens of millions of people in a worldwide pandemic. Safe and effective vaccines are needed urgently.

title: CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing in human embryos
abstract: CRISPR-Cas9 is a revolutionary gene-editing tool that has transformed biological research and holds promise for treating genetic diseases. This study explores its application in human embryos.

title: Machine learning approaches for predicting protein-protein interactions
abstract: Protein-protein interactions (PPIs) are fundamental to virtually every biological process. Computational prediction of PPIs can guide experimental studies and provide insights into cellular mechanisms.

title: Quantum supremacy using a programmable superconducting processor
abstract: The promise of quantum computers is that certain computational tasks might be executed exponentially faster on a quantum processor than on a classical processor.

title: Global burden of cardiovascular diseases and risk factors
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases remain the leading cause of death globally. Understanding trends in cardiovascular disease burden and risk factors is essential for policy making.

title: Room-temperature superconductivity in a carbonaceous sulfur hydride
abstract: The discovery of superconductivity at high pressure in hydrides has transformed the landscape of superconductivity research. Here we report superconductivity at 15Â°C in a carbonaceous sulfur hydride.

title: Deep learning for genomics: A comprehensive review
abstract: Deep learning has emerged as a powerful tool for analyzing genomic data. This review discusses recent advances in applying deep neural networks to genomic problems.

title: Mental health and COVID-19: Global perspectives
abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic has had profound effects on mental health worldwide. This study examines the psychological impact and strategies for mitigation.

title: Neuroplasticity and brain-computer interfaces
abstract: Brain-computer interfaces leverage neuroplasticity to enable direct communication between the brain and external devices, with applications in rehabilitation and assistive technology.

title: Federated learning for privacy-preserving machine learning
abstract: Federated learning enables training machine learning models across decentralized devices while keeping data localized, addressing privacy concerns in the era of big data.

title: Recent developments in algebraic topology
abstract: This survey covers recent advances in algebraic topology, including applications to data science and topological data analysis.

title: Quantum error correction and fault-tolerant quantum computing
abstract: Quantum error correction is essential for building reliable quantum computers. This paper presents new protocols for fault-tolerant quantum computation.

title: Single-cell genomics: technological advances and biological insights
abstract: Single-cell genomics has revolutionized our understanding of cellular heterogeneity. This review highlights technological innovations and biological discoveries.

title: Climate tipping points and irreversible changes
abstract: Climate tipping points represent thresholds beyond which systems may transition to different states. Understanding these is critical for climate policy.

title: Light-driven carbon dioxide reduction with artificial photosynthesis
abstract: Artificial photosynthesis offers a sustainable approach to converting CO2 into fuels and chemicals using sunlight, mimicking natural photosynthetic processes.

title: Database resources for biological research in 2021
abstract: This article surveys major biological databases and their recent updates, providing researchers with essential resources for genomic and proteomic studies.

title: Neural correlates of consciousness: Current theories and evidence
abstract: Understanding the neural basis of consciousness remains one of neuroscience's greatest challenges. This review examines leading theories and experimental evidence.

title: Social media and mental health in adolescents
abstract: The relationship between social media use and adolescent mental health is complex. This longitudinal study examines causal pathways and protective factors.

title: Machine learning methods for causal inference in social sciences
abstract: Machine learning offers powerful tools for causal inference, but requires careful application. This paper provides guidance for social science researchers.

title: Interpretable machine learning: definitions, methods, and applications
abstract: As machine learning systems are deployed in high-stakes domains, interpretability becomes crucial. This review covers methods for making ML models interpretable.

title: RNA modifications and their role in gene expression
abstract: Post-transcriptional RNA modifications regulate gene expression through diverse mechanisms. This review covers recent discoveries in epitranscriptomics.

title: Detection of gravitational waves from neutron star mergers
abstract: Gravitational wave astronomy has opened a new window on the universe. This paper reports observations of neutron star mergers and their electromagnetic counterparts.

title: Cognitive biases in decision making: A systematic review
abstract: Cognitive biases systematically influence human judgment and decision making. This review synthesizes findings across domains and proposes interventions.

title: Biodiversity loss and ecosystem functioning
abstract: Biodiversity is declining at unprecedented rates globally. This meta-analysis examines how species loss affects ecosystem services and resilience.

title: Open science practices and reproducibility in research
abstract: Reproducibility is fundamental to scientific progress. This study evaluates the adoption of open science practices across disciplines.

title: Global health equity and access to healthcare
abstract: Health inequities persist both within and between countries. This analysis examines barriers to healthcare access and policy solutions.

title: Microplastics in the environment: sources, fate, and impacts
abstract: Microplastics contamination is a growing environmental concern. This review synthesizes current knowledge on sources, distribution, and ecological effects.

title: Network analysis in systems biology
abstract: Network approaches provide powerful frameworks for understanding biological systems. This review covers methods and applications in systems biology.

title: Ancient DNA reveals human migration patterns
abstract: Ancient DNA analysis has revolutionized our understanding of human prehistory. This study traces migration patterns across continents over millennia.

title: Immunology of COVID-19: Current understanding and questions
abstract: Understanding immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 is critical for developing vaccines and therapeutics. This review summarizes current knowledge.

title: Topological quantum materials and their applications
abstract: Topological materials exhibit exotic properties protected by topology. This review discusses recent discoveries and potential applications in quantum technologies.

title: The science of behavior change: challenges and opportunities
abstract: Changing human behavior is central to addressing many societal challenges. This review examines effective interventions based on psychological science.

title: Artificial intelligence in drug discovery
abstract: AI is transforming pharmaceutical research by accelerating drug discovery and development. This perspective discusses opportunities and challenges.

title: Sustainable materials for a circular economy
abstract: Transitioning to a circular economy requires developing sustainable materials that can be recycled or biodegraded. This review examines promising approaches.

title: Urban planning and climate adaptation strategies
abstract: Cities face increasing climate risks. This study examines urban planning strategies for building resilience and adapting to climate change.

title: Plant responses to drought stress: molecular mechanisms
abstract: Drought is a major constraint on crop productivity. Understanding plant stress responses at molecular level can guide breeding for drought tolerance.

title: Long-term outcomes of COVID-19 survivors
abstract: Many COVID-19 survivors experience persistent symptoms. This cohort study examines long-term health outcomes and identifies risk factors.

title: Computational modeling of infectious disease spread
abstract: Mathematical models are essential tools for understanding and controlling infectious diseases. This review covers recent advances in epidemic modeling.

title: Neural basis of learning and memory consolidation
abstract: Memory consolidation involves complex neural processes that stabilize learned information. This review synthesizes findings from systems neuroscience.

title: Renewable energy transitions: technological and policy perspectives
abstract: Transitioning to renewable energy is critical for climate mitigation. This analysis examines technological advances and policy frameworks.

title: Metabolic regulation of immune cell function
abstract: Cellular metabolism shapes immune responses. This review discusses how metabolic pathways regulate immune cell differentiation and function.

title: Explainable AI: methods and applications
abstract: As AI systems become more complex, explainability is crucial for trust and accountability. This paper surveys methods for making AI decisions transparent.

title: Earth system modeling and climate prediction
abstract: Earth system models integrate physical, chemical, and biological processes to project future climate. This review examines recent advances and uncertainties.

title: Psychological resilience: mechanisms and interventions
abstract: Resilience enables individuals to adapt to adversity. This review examines psychological and neurobiological mechanisms underlying resilience.

title: Cultural evolution and human behavior
abstract: Cultural evolution shapes human societies through transmission and modification of behaviors. This paper presents an integrative theoretical framework.

title: Synthetic biology for sustainable production
abstract: Synthetic biology enables engineering organisms for sustainable production of chemicals, fuels, and materials. This perspective discusses opportunities.

title: Genomic medicine: from research to clinical practice
abstract: Genomic technologies are transforming medicine. This review examines progress in translating genomic discoveries into clinical applications.
